alignments-dialog.title: Alignments for {name}
alignments-dialog.page-hint: Replays every trace from the given event log on the model and shows compatible and deviating moves.

edit.name: Name
edit.name-hint: The label shown on top of this component
edit.type-hint: The type of component to display
edit.query-doc: Open PQL documentation in a new window
edit.query-hint: The query executed against the selected data store for retrieval of event logs for this component
edit.datastore-hint: The data store to execute the query against

validation.not-a-non-negative-integer: The value must be a non-negative integer

edit.horizon: Valid only for Online Heuristic Miner. How many events forward in the trace to consider as possible effects of an activity.

flat-log.log-deviation: An event in the log not corresponding to the process model
flat-log.model-deviation: An activity in the model not corresponding to the event in the log

data-stores.page-hint: A data store keeps event logs, configuration for data connectors to remote data sources, and configuration of ETL processes. The data stores are recommended to correspond to projects and/or organizational units.
data-stores.name-hint: Name helps you identify the data store in all components configurable using the data store. The name is recommended to be unique.
data-stores.logs-hint: The list of event logs consists of individual event logs stored in this data store. It is recommended that one event log correspond to one business process. Each event log consists of traces corresponding to the business cases of a process. Each trace consists of events raised during process execution. Logs, traces, and events are described using attributes. Event logs adhere to the eXtensible Event Stream (XES) IEEE 1849-2016 standard.
data-stores.data-connectors-hint: A data connector consists of the configuration database connection, e.g., database type, address, username, and password.
data-stores.etl-processes-hint: The list of Extract, Transformation, Load (ETL) processes consists of individual processes defined in this data store. An ETL process is a configurable pipeline for extracting data using a data connector, transforming them into the form of event log, and loading into the data store. The automatic ETL processes uses machine learning to detect the structure and semantics of the data to configure the transformation. The manual ETL processes relies on manual configuration of the transformation.
data-stores.data-connector-required: A data connector is required to add continuous ETL process

automatic-etl-process.title: Add automatic ETL process
automatic-etl-process.description: Automatically infer a business perspective and start monitoring the data changes
automatic-etl-process.case-notion-description: for each entry in {source} related to an entry in {target}

jdbc-etl-process.title: Add JDBC ETL process
jdbc-etl-process.description: Manually define a query that yields relevant events as result rows
jdbc-etl-process.trigger: Execute the process once at the earliest possible moment

upload-xes-file.title: Upload XES event log
upload-xes-file.description: Upload event log file in the eXtensible Event Stream (XES) format containing the recording of a business process execution

data-stores.data-store-not-found: No appropriate data store found to query
data-stores.file-size-exceeded: The selected file exceeds the size limit
data-stores.removal-confirmation: Do you want to permanently remove {dataStoreName} data store?
data-stores.data-connector-removal-confirmation: Do you want to permanently remove {dataConnectorName} data connector?

etl.removal-confirmation: Do you want to permanently remove {etlProcessName} ETL process with all associated data?
etl.deactivation-confirmation: Do you want to stop tracking changes in {etlProcessName} ETL process?

jdbc-etl-process-dialog.query-hint: Type an SQL query that produces one event per row. The SQL dialect depends on the data connector/source database. The resulting columns are transformed into event attributes, omitting NULL values. For each row, the columns corresponding to unique and durable event and trace identifiers must be provided. Two types of queries are supported: batch and continuous. The batch query extracts, transforms, and loads event log on demand all-at-once. The continuous query executes periodically to extract, transform, and load new events that occurred since the last query execution. For continuous query, a condition, e.g., a WHERE clause, must be provided for filtering out already loaded events. This condition must use exactly one binding variable, e.g., ?, that attains the value of the id of the last loaded event.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.batch-hint: Two types of queries are supported: batch and continuous. The batch query extracts, transforms, and loads event log on demand all-at-once. The continuous query executes periodically to extract, transform, and load new events that occurred since the last query execution.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.refresh-hint: For continuous query only: time between the successive executions of the SQL query.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.trace-id-source-hint: The name of the column in the SQL query storing the trace id.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.trace-id-target-hint: The name of the trace attribute to store its id. Recommended values: identity:id or concept:name.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.event-id-source-hint: The name of the column in the SQL query  storing the event id.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.event-id-target-hint: The name of the event attribute to store its id. Recommended values: identity:id or concept:name.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.mappings-hint: An optional mapping of columns in the SQL query into event attributes. The unmapped columns are directly converted to attributes.

validation.not-a-positive-integer: The value is not a positive integer

jdbc-etl-process-dialog.last-event-external-id-hint: For continuous query only: the id corresponding to the event before the first event to extract; it may be fake value. This value is assigned to the only binding variable of the SQL query on its first execution.
jdbc-etl-process-dialog.last-event-external-id-type-hint: For continuous query only: the type of the initial event id. This type is used to supply the database driver with the correct type of the value.

add-data-connector-dialog.connection-string-hint: Use JDBC format, e.g., jdbc:driver://host:port/database?user=login&password=password. Driver corresponds to the specific database driver. Supported values are: postgres, sqlserver, mysql, oracle, db2. The remaining part depends on the driver. Please follow the documentation of the database management system.
add-data-connector-dialog.connector-not-supported: Connection string based connectors are not yet supported

validation.connection-string-format: The value doesn't conform to connection string format
validation.hostname-field: The value should be valid hostname or IP address
validation.port-field: The value should be integer from 0-65535 range
